awd_titl_txt: NeTS: JUNO2: Collaborative Research: STEAM: Secure and Trustworthy Framework for Integrated Energy and Mobility in Smart Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid evolution of data-driven analytics, Internet of things (IoT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) are fueling a growing set of Smart and Connected Communities (SCC) applications, including for smart transportation and smart energy.  However, the deployment of such technological solutions without proper security mechanisms makes them susceptible to data integrity and privacy attacks, as observed in a large number of recent incidents. If not addressed properly, such attacks will not only cripple SCC operations but also influence the extent to which customers are willing to share data. This in turn will make trustworthiness in SCC applications very challenging. To address this, a synergistic team of researchers from the US and Japan, under the JUNO2 program,  will collaborate on this project, called STEAM (Secure and Trustworthy framework for integrated Energy and Mobility) to develop a  framework to ensure data privacy, data integrity, and trustworthiness in smart and connected communities. The collaboration provides the project with a significant amount of automotive (transportation) data from Japan, and also access to a testbed in Japan. Although the target applications are smart mobility and smart energy (the choice is deliberate to exploit the complementary strengths of Japan and US in these two domains), the proposed techniques and solutions have wide applicability to other domains, such as smart healthcare. 

The novelty of the STEAM project lies in its integrated approach to handling security and trustworthiness in SCC applications. Specifically, the research team will develop innovative privacy-preserving algorithms and models for anomaly detection, trust and reputation scoring used by application providers for data integrity and information assurance. Towards that goal, they will study trade-offs between security, privacy, trust levels, resources, and performance using two exemplar applications in smart mobility and smart energy exchange in communities. Finally, they will design a modular, secure and trustworthy middleware architecture that implements privacy-preserving algorithms, resource constraints, and trustworthiness of data sources or content and decision-making schemes. The project has access to smart meter data from Texas, California, and Ireland and a large volume of automobile data from Japan.  The evaluation plan includes integration of the project's anomaly detection and trustworthy decision-making algorithms into a smart vehicle route planning application and a transactive energy system in a plug-in electric vehicle testbed in Japan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Through the Japan-US Network Opportunity 2 (JUNO2), teams from various US and Japanese universities collaborated to solve problems in the domain of transportation. As modern cities continuously grow, traffic and congestion have grown worse, requiring smarter transportation solutions. In recent years the increasing ubiquity of small-form computing devices has allowed stakeholders access to an unprecedented amount of data on various aspects of transportation. The work under JUNO2 began with attempting to utilize road-side units, small form devices located by roads that gather traffic data, as decentralized computing resources. The team developed a framework called Information Flow of Things that can be deployed on available computing resources which allows for tasks to be processed in a distributed manner. This framework was used to plan and generate routes based on traffic data from Nashville, TN, giving users an accurate and efficient method for route planning while keeping all processing in-city, which has many implications for reliability, security, and quality of services.

 Various other smart transportation solutions, which leverage this distributed framework, were explored by the team. The decentralized setup was inherently suitable for maintaining user privacy which led to the development of a user-centric distributed route planning framework that optimizes privacy, throughput, and accuracy of user preferences. This work also leverages prior work done with privacy-preserving anomaly-based attack detection on the smart grid, adapted to smart transportation.

 This distributed property of the system was also used as the basis for an anomaly detection framework. Our approach divides the city into clusters and uses an invariant metric for detecting traffic anomalies. Without the clustering and division of the city, the approach would be impractical and infeasible. Additionally, data had to be cleaned and augmented before being used to enable learning of the underlying structure of benign conditions.

Finally, the team explored modern encryption methods and developed efficient algorithms to perform anomaly detection on encrypted datasets. To show the generalization of the approach the team also explored application of the methodology on smart energy problems that have similar network structure to the transportation problem.

Overall, in the smart energy domain, we have three joint publications where we showed how anomaly detection can be performed on smart meter data without the utility company ever accessing individual meter's data in plaintext yet the accuracy with fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) is preserved. Along with FHE, we showed how private information retrieval and elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) can be used to enhance privacy and improve performance.  Experimental results confirmed that our proposed method can detect the injection of false power consumption in the range of 11-17 secs of execution time, depending on the detection accuracy, with a lookup table based FHE approach with private information retrieval.  The extension of ECC-based Homomorphic encryption of smart meter data was able to achieve 18 times faster results compared to the commonly used CKKS scheme. 

For smart transportation, our joint work led to key results across the middleware for running the decentralized routing algorithms and anomaly detection algorithms that can identify if the traffic data is being manipulated. All the algorithms were tested on the transportation network datasets in Nashville, Tennessee and Osaka, Japan. Our collaboration considered specific threat vectors to the transportation ecosystem. Specifically, we consider that sensors can fail silently, provide random data, or coordinated misinformation to change the current routing algorithms. We have shown that our algorithms can detect security problems with a high accuracy. 


Last Modified: 12/18/2022
Modified by: Abhishek Dubey
por.por_txt_cntn:
Through the Japan-US Network Opportunity 2 (JUNO2), teams from various US and Japanese universities collaborated to solve problems in the domain of transportation. As modern cities continuously grow, traffic and congestion have grown worse, requiring smarter transportation solutions. In recent years the increasing ubiquity of small-form computing devices has allowed stakeholders access to an unprecedented amount of data on various aspects of transportation. This framework was used to plan and generate routes based on traffic data from Nashville, TN, giving users an accurate and efficient method for route planning while keeping all processing in-city, which has many implications for reliability, security, and quality of services.

 Various other smart transportation solutions, which leverage this distributed framework, were explored by the team. The decentralized setup was inherently suitable for maintaining user privacy which led to the development of a user-centric distributed route planning framework that optimizes privacy, throughput, and accuracy of user preferences. This work also leverages prior work done with privacy-preserving anomaly-based attack detection on the smart grid, adapted to smart transportation.

 This distributed property of the system was also used as the basis for an anomaly detection framework. Without the clustering and division of the city, the approach would be impractical and infeasible. For smart transportation, our joint work led to key results across the middleware for running the decentralized routing algorithms and anomaly detection algorithms that can identify if the traffic data is being manipulated. We have shown that our algorithms can detect security problems with a high accuracy.
